title: 'No imminent risk' for Syd Mascot Towers
text:
Sydney's Mascot Towers will be closed to owners for urgent remedial works, but engineers say the building is not at immediate risk despite new cracks being found.

The 132-apartment tower was evacuated in mid-June after cracking was found in the primary support structure and facade masonry.

New advice from a structural engineer - sent to owners and residents on Tuesday - suggested the building's existing cracks have widened.

Additionally, new cracking has developed in or around the building's northeast transfer beam and all basement parking levels.

Increased cracking in the basement footing slab - which supports the towers - is also of "significant concern", the update said.

Mascot Towers will be closed to owners from Thursday, with the building's owners' corporation moving towards urgent remediation.

It said engineers were confident the building was not at imminent risk, but could be if "immediate" steps weren't taken to improve the bearing capacity of the basement footing slab.

An engineering plan is in place with cracking closely monitored, a spokesman for the owners' corporation said.

"The engineers are confident that they have the situation under control provided that the under-slab soil remediation gets under way," the spokesman said on Wednesday.

"The building itself remains stable but the remediation must start as soon as possible."
